description.plain:
Nayvadius DeMun Wilburn (b. November 20, 1983), popularly known as Future, is an American rapper and singer from Kirkwood, Atlanta, Georgia. He is signed to Epic Records. He is the cousin of Rocko and Rico Wade and a former associate of the Dungeon Family. He first rapped under the stage name Meathead.

Future has made himself known for his extensive use of auto-tune, producing a flurry of hit singles such as “Fuck Up Some Commas” and “Turn On The Lights”, among others.

Future is also known for his hook singing on tracks such as “Buy The World”, “U.O.E.N.O, “Loveeeeee Song” & “Pain”.

Future was at one point engaged to singer Ciara and they have a child, Future Jr., but they broke up—due to Future apparently not wanting a very extravagant wedding. He later went on to say:

I can’t have no big wedding on E! News. … I can’t have all these different big media outlets cover my wedding and I’m not comfortable. … I’m not comfortable about where I’m at in my career. I’m not comfortable about compromising about just being the person that I am, being the man that I am. I feel like my better judgment is to go back and record and make music.

He is closely associated to Atlanta producers DJ Esco, Southside, Metro Boomin, Sonny Digital & Zaytoven.

He’s the first artist in history to have back-to-back number one album debuts after releasing FUTURE and HNDRXX a week apart from each other in 2017.

songs.title: Mask Off

description.plain:
“Mask Off” serves as a “rags-to-riches” story that explores the surface of Future’s past, from trapping to living a life of luxury. The slow and syrupy production by Metro Boomin samples the 1976 song, “Prison Song” by Tommy Butler, which featured Carlton Williams.

The song went on to become one of Future’s highest-charting singles ever, peaking at #5 on the Billboard Hot 100. The song is also certified 6X platinum by the RIAA.

https://twitter.com/1future/status/854531549798080512

The song also spawned the #MaskOffChallenge, which participants dance and play instruments to the song. It was a huge factor in the song’s popularity.

The song’s official music video was released on May 4, 2017, and two weeks later, on May 23, 2017, a remix featuring Kendrick Lamar was released.

songs.full_title: Low Life by Future (Ft. The Weeknd)
songs.title: Low Life

description.plain:
A lowlife is defined by Merriam-Webster as a “bad person: person of low moral character.”

The title of The Weeknd and Future’s song suggests a reference to the word’s meaning, and their lyrics detail the activities they consider to be a part of a “low life:” drugs, alcohol, strippers, cheating, murder, and spending exorbitant amounts of money.

In addition to referencing the term lowlife, this song can be interpreted as a play on the term “high life,” generally understood as a luxurious lifestyle afforded to the rich and famous. As supporters of the “low life,” The Weeknd and Future turn “high life” accommodations into austere ones.

The Weeknd released “Low Life” as a Christmas gift for their fans after some teasing. His “Pass Dat (Remix)” was also included in the mini-release. “Low Life” was later revealed to be included on Future’s album EVOL.

https://twitter.com/theweeknd/status/680256090219646976

songs.full_title: Life Is Good by Future (Ft. Drake)
songs.title: Life Is Good

description.plain:
On “Life Is Good,” Future enlists the help of frequent collaborator Drake for their first collaboration since June 2018’s “Blue Tint.” Although the song was released as a collaboration, it’s divided in two solo songs.

The track was initially previewed on Future’s Instagram Live on December 18, 2019. Between then and the track’s official release, Future and Drake teased it multiple times—most notably on January 6, 2020 when Drake teased the track’s imminent release and revealed its title via his Instagram story.

On January 9, 2020, Future revealed its release date on The New REAL 106.1 radio station, where he also confirmed that Drake was strictly a feature on the track, making the rumors of a sequel to What a Time to Be Alive unlikely.

songs.title: March Madness

description.plain:
“March Madness” is the nickname for the NCAA basketball championship tournament. The tournament consists of the country’s top 68 teams, all battling for one championship.

While Future references drugs, fast cars, and clear-cut diamonds, there is a social message throughout the song. He mentions police shootings and features civil rights clips in the music video.

The song began to catch on in popular culture after LeBron James was seen warming up to it before the NBA Finals.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=XkfjB76sau0

songs.full_title: Where Ya At by Future (Ft. Drake)
songs.title: Where Ya At

description.plain:
“Where Ya At” is the only song on Future’s album DS2 to feature another artist—at one point he had said there would be no features, but he had to make an exception for Drake. The song is an ode to Drake’s old motto no new friends.

The song serves as a defiant ode to people who try to come back and profit off of Drake and Future’s success after abandoning them during their struggles.

The music video features iconic rooftop dancing from Future and his close collaborators Metro Boomin and DJ Esco, the coolest DJ in the world.

https://twitter.com/Drake/status/619529041993965568?lang=en

songs.full_title: Comin Out Strong by Future (Ft. The Weeknd)
songs.title: Comin Out Strong

description.plain:
The Weeknd and Future’s fourth collaboration. This song has both artists flexing and “coming out strong” despite haters and people that doubt them, that go out of their way to hinder their success.

Such people go as far as falsifying allegations against them, making stories up if they have none. They taunt haters throughout the song repeatedly asking “do you know who I am?” in each verse.

In the last verse Future also addresses his legal disputes against his former manager, Rocko.

songs.full_title: Fuck Up Some Commas by Future
songs.title: Fuck Up Some Commas

description.plain:
The fifth song off Future’s 2014 mixtape Monster, and the final track off his 2015 album DS2, the punishing beat from DJ Spinz and Southside has become anthemic in 2015.

This turn-up jam spawned an official remix, and made its way around the freestyle circuit, most famously in Cleveland rapper Ezzy’s on Sway In The Morning.

songs.full_title: I Won by Future (Ft. Kanye West)
songs.title: I Won

description.plain:
Originally dubbed “Trophy Wife,” this Metro Boomin-produced track finds Future and Yeezy toasting to the sweetest of arm candies over clashing snares and elephant feet drums. It even has its own game.

“I Won” isn’t usually a term of endearment, but Future and Kanye West — both of whom are engaged to beautiful, famous women and are fathering children with them — built an entire song on the concept that there’s nothing more romantic than being dubbed life’s grand prize, having a person to spend the rest of their life with.

Future on working with Kanye:

That’s rare when you get a Kanye verse back in one day, so you know it’s one of them records when he does the verse and sends it back in 24 hours. That’s the icing on the cake with the album.

songs.full_title: Thought It Was a Drought by Future
songs.title: Thought It Was a Drought

description.plain:
“Thought It Was A Drought” kicks off the DS2 album where Future speaks on his love for cough syrup, speaks on his drug-dealing come-up & successes, while subtly dropping hints towards his break-up with Ciara.

In this case, the “drought” is the lack of Actavis cough syrup since it was removed from the market following its numerous references in music. Future isn’t experiencing the drought because he’s well-connected.

songs.full_title: Used to This by Future (Ft. Drake)
songs.title: Used to This

description.plain:
“Used to This” sees Future and Drake celebrating their successes. They spit braggadocios bars about partying with “the real Madonna,” and making lifestyle choices like purchasing luxury cars and houses in the hills to demonstrate how accustomed they’ve become to wealth and fame.

The song was originally meant to appear on the sequel to Future’s Beast Mode mixtape, which was slated for a 2016 release but delayed until 2018.

songs.title: Trap Niggas

description.plain:
The ‘trap’ Future speaks of on this song isn’t necessarily a bando. Future wanted this song to be motivational for all kinds of people:

It’s just motivation…if you working every day 9 to 5, you could be a dancer in the club, a waitress…wherever you make your money at, wherever you get your hustle on at, that’s your trap. I feel like we use trapped as in trapped in a position where you can’t get out, so I’m adding more life to the word, making it uplifting…so even if you trapped, your gonna be blessed to get out that situation

This track appears on both Future’s 56 Nights mixtape and his third studio album Dirty Sprite 2.

Another single off of Future’s sophomore studio album effort ‘Honest’ which features King Push, Pharrell and Casino, some of Coke Rap’s biggest names. It even has its own game.

songs.title: Stick Talk

description.plain:
In “Stick Talk” we see Future take full control of his environment as he boasts about his riches, exotic vehicles, effect drug-dealing, and most importantly, how he’s got a way with guns.

While introducing Future at the 2016 MTV VMAs, Olympic swimmer Michael Phelps confirmed he was listening to this song in his infamous viral photo from the Rio Olympics.

songs.full_title: Mask Off (Remix) by Future (Ft. Kendrick Lamar)
songs.title: Mask Off (Remix)

description.plain:
After teasing the collab hours before its release, Future enlists Kendrick for their second joint effort. Future’s “Mask Off” is his most popular song yet as the leading artist, notably because of the use of the flute and catchy lyrics.

The track features Future’s original bars as well as the chorus, whilst Kendrick boasts of his mainstream and critical success, and his position at the top of the rap game.

songs.title: Selfish

description.plain:
Rihanna and Future’s second collaboration finds them crooning about coming back together from a broken relationship of “lies,“ "wrong turns,” and “wrong words” for each others' selfish pleasures, so that they are “not alone” for the night.

Rihanna previously featured Future on her 2012 hit “Loveeeeee Song” and he also wrote her collaboration with Mike WiLL Made-It: “Nothing Is Promised”.

songs.title: Purple Reign

description.plain: Aside from the nod to Prince’s album Purple Rain, this song is inextricably linked to Future’s lean abuse and his reign over the rap game. While climbing the ladder of success, Future has become hopelessly addicted to lean, such that it reigns over his own life. In his mind, lean has become his lover, upon whom he is dependent.

songs.full_title: Turn On the Lights by Future
songs.title: Turn On the Lights

description.plain:
A full quarter of Turn on the Lights passes before the beat finally drops, but it’s that floaty and ambient structure that makes Future’s longing so articulate.

It also made a surprise hit for both the artist and it’s producer – Mike WiLL Made It. The track hit #2 on the R&B/Hip-Hop charts, effectively launching both of their careers. In a Complex interview, Mike WiLL said of the song:

Future was like, “Man, basically you’re telling me to sing it. What are you trying to turn me into, an R&B singer?” I was like, “Bob Marley wasn’t no R&B singer. You know you’re not an R&B singer. You just got an ill tone.”

The breakthrough helped define Future’s strange and lyrical sound, setting the stage for another equally successful single, a star-studded sophomore album, and a new movement in hip-hop, one that stretches from young thug to desiigner. Yet despite both collaborator’s tremendous futures, Turn On the Lights remains unique in it’s sound and vision.

songs.title: Perkys Calling

description.plain:
This song is Future describing his mindset when he is sober. His drug addiction has consumed his thoughts and whenever he isn’t on drugs, he is constantly thinking about getting high. Future really opens up about just how bad his addiction is.

The sample that Southside uses comes from composer Goldmund’s “Threnody.”

songs.title: Rich $ex

description.plain:
Future’s net worth is around $30 million, he is into the finer things in life: Rollies, chains and VVS diamonds. The title itself, “Rich $ex”, is a play on being rich – the dollar sign is used instead of an “S”.

Future also dropped a video for the song on November 19th 2015, featuring Tyga’s baby mama Blac Chyna. Speculation went wild, as Nov. 19th is also Tyga’s birthday.

songs.title: Blow a Bag

description.plain:
“Blow a Bag” is a song celebrating spending a ridiculous amount of money at once — either a bag of money or blowing a “bag” of weed.  Future is no stranger to a “Shopping Spree” as a way of masking his pain, which even drugs can’t cure like he explained on “Hardly”.

Future describes his shopping habits on “Poppin' Tags”.

 The official music video dropped July 10, 2015: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=jfmc5pyISeE

songs.full_title: The Percocet & Stripper Joint by Future
songs.title: The Percocet & Stripper Joint

description.plain: “The Percocet & Stripper Joint” is about Future’s addiction to Percocets—a painkiller which includes the combination of oxycodone and paracetamol (aka acetaminophen or Tylenol); in this track, Future highlights the extent of his drug use—even stretching to painkillers—while he’s in a strip club.

songs.title: Lay Up

description.plain:
Lay Up, coming off the second track from the Beast Mode mixtape. A layup in basketball is a two-point shot attempt made by leaping from below, laying the ball up near the basket, and using one hand to bounce it off the backboard and into the basket. In a nutshell its a great way to stunt on the opposing team to attain points, in similar fashion, Future lays up on haters.

Also, being loyal to his “Monster Monday” series, he drops a music video to this song on May 28, 2015.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7M8k8Xl43IY

songs.full_title: You da Baddest by Future (Ft. Nicki Minaj)
songs.title: You da Baddest

description.plain:
“You Da Baddest” marks the first direct collaboration between Future and Nicki Minaj, after appearing on numerous songs together as featured artists (not including their 2014 unreleased track, “Rockstar”).  It is the third collaborative single that Future has put out since releasing the albums FUTURE and HNDRXX, preceded by “PIE” with Chris Brown and “Extra Luv” with YG, both of which were added to the streaming versions of the albums. It was originally scheduled for a July 21 release, however it was delayed and ended up surfacing online on July 22.

It was officially released on July 28 and subsequently added to the streaming version of HNDRXX.

songs.title: PIE

description.plain:
”PIE” is a collaborative R&B track by Future and Chris Brown, released with an accompanying music video via Future’s official VEVO on June 26, 2017. Prior to this single, Future and Chris Brown collaborated on 2015’s “U Did It” from Chris Brown’s Royalty album, and even performed together in Atlanta for Chris Brown’s ”The Party Tour”.

Chris Brown previewed ”PIE” previously on January 9, 2017 in the Avenue Nightclub in New York, which accommodated different lyrics compared to the final version of it.

songs.title: Incredible

description.plain: On “Incredible,” Future pays homage to the girl’s moves in bed and her loyalty. Throughout the song, he thanks her for changing his original ways from not trusting women to being open and believing. The song continues to develop, as it follows Future through the process of falling and love and changing for the better.

songs.title: Inside the Mattress

description.plain: Sunday morning taking in the new Future tape, a few favorites have been tossed around on Twitter. “Inside The Mattress” seems to have the greatest consensus, and happens to be the only on the track produced by long-time Future collaborators Nard & B. The duo has worked on classics from “Straight Up” to “Throw Away”, making them one of Fewtch’s best matches, but also one of his most underrated.

songs.title: Solitaires

description.plain:
On “Solitaires,” Future reunites with Travis Scott on a song in which they trade boastful bars about their luxurious lifestyles, from the luxury fashion brands they can afford to the jewelry and cars they own. They also drop bars on the COVID-19 pandemic, an ongoing disease at the time of this song’s release, to compare their diamonds.

This song’s instrumental is produced by Wheezy, who frequently produces songs for Future. It is also co-produced by MIKE DEAN, who frequently produces songs for Travis.

A snippet of this song surfaced to the public a few hours before its release of Future playing the song in the studio with Travis.

songs.title: Never Stop

description.plain: “Never Stop” serves as the intro track to Future’s seventh studio album, The WIZRD. The introspective track features Future rapping for a single verse for almost four minutes straight; the song focuses on his life and struggles, detailing how he made it to the top over an ambient beat courtesy of Billboard Hitmakers and ATL Jacob.
